data.title: Road to Morocco (1942)
data.meta_description: Two carefree castaways on a desert shore find an Arabian Nights city, where they compete for the luscious Princess Shalmar.
data.text:
Why don't the kids watch the Hope movies anymore?

Bob Hope was one of the most popular comedians for an entire lifetime, and now... ROAD TO MOROCCO is probably the only one most people could mention off-hand.

Some jokes made me chuckle, the sets are big and lavish, and Director David Butler keeps things moving, but this is the definition of a slightly amusing comedy that someone older than forces you to watch because they loved it when they were a kid.

Now, ABBOTT AND COSTELLO, THE THREE STOOGES, LAUREL AND HARDY, THE MARX BROTHERS, those boys still hold up.

Anyway, Bing Crosby is such a jerk in this. He sells Bob Hope into slavery, and once he learns Bob…

A Year of Film History Challenge 2019

(watching a little bit of film history month by month, decade by decade)

--

I love when a movie surprisingly turns out to be exactly what you needed at the time you watch it, and Bob Hope & Bing Crosby's third road movie Road to Morocco turned out to be exactly that for me on a real bummer of a day. Hope and Crosby were already consummate entertainers on their own by this point, and so their pairing here is great; they know just how to play off of and balance each other in a way that never feels excessively self-indulgent, but instead (in that old showbiz way) always aims to please the viewer.…

Release date April 8th 1943

If you are unaware of these ‘road films’ , you are in luck , even the bad ones are good enough.

My favorite of the “Road” films, this is the third of the seven starring Bob Hope, Bing Crosby and Dorothy Lamour.

This film was selected to the National Film Registry, Library of Congress, in 1996.

Included among the American Film Institute's 2004 list of the top 100 America's Greatest Music in the Movies for the song "(We're Off on the) Road to Morocco."

Included among the American Film Institute's 1998 list of the 400 movies nominated for the Top 100 Greatest American Movies.

Dorothy Lamour commented that the "boys" ad-libbed their lines so much…
